dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man strides up a grassy hill. He is in his late-30s, cl shaven with shaggy hair. He wears a well-cut tweed riding jacket, jodhpurs and riding boots. He carries a large shillelagh which rests on his shoulder. This is CAM STUART. He sings with gusto, a Civil War marching song.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: .--John Brown's body lies a- mouldering in the grave/ John Brown's body lies a-mouldering in the grave John Brown's body lies a-mouldering in the grave His soul is marching on/ Glory, glory hallelulah/ Glory, glory hallelulah... At the top of the hill there is a boulder. It catches his eye and he cocks his head, bemused. Laid out on the surface of the rock is a cheap fake beard He looks around. There is not a person or a building in sight. The tall grass bends in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HILLSIDE. DAY
dialogues.text: Cam, now wearing the fake beard, stands on the rock, gazi out imperiously. He takes several deep breaths through hi nose, appreciating the fresh air. Then he jumps off the boulder and continues his song as he marches down the hil

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: He's gone to be a soldier in the army of the Lord/ He's gone to be a soldier in the army of the Lord/ He's gone to be a soldier in the army of the Lord... He disappears from view. A TITLE CARD READS: 1978. INT. CHILDS’ BEDROOM. NIGHT In the darkness, we hear:

dialogues.speaker: CAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Girls, wake up. Wake up.  A flashlight clicks on. It swings between two sleeping children. Two bi-racial girls are sprawled out asleep on their beds AMELIA is ten; FAITH is eight. Cam shakes them. waking. He pulls their twisted covers off.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Rise and shine. They resist Finally they sit up. They blink at him, disoriented, shielding their eyes from the glare of the flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: CAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Happy birthday, Amelia. Amelia turns on her bedside lamp.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: It’s not my birthday. Cam is disheveled and dirty, still wearing the tweed ridi jacket, jodhpurs, riding boots and fake beard. wide, wet and burning.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: You look ridiculous. Why are you wearing that beard?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Do you like it?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Then it’s history! He rips off the beard and throws it to the floor. eye him warily.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Where were you last night? Mommy was worried.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You smell like mothballs.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Good nose, Faithie. This riding outfit belonged to Great-Grandpapa. We’re exactly the same size. Cam admires the craftsmanship of the jacket. His eyes are The girls

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hand-stitched by blind nuns.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Wasn’t everything hand-stitched back then?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Not by blind nuns.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Where’s Mommy?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Sleeping. Shhh. Faith collapses back onto her pillow, whimpering.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HILL. DAY
dialogues.text: Cam, without the fake beard, marches up the hill as the s comes up. His daughters hurry behind him, still half-asle They both wear sweaters over their nightgowns. He stops t look at the sunrise and takes a long drag on his cigarett

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: It’s going to be one hell of a hot day.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I'm freezing. She looks like she’s going to cry.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Take my jacket, Faithie. I don’t need it. Are you cold, Amelia? He puts his jacket on Faith. Teeth chattering, Amelia sha her head no. Cam pats her approvingly on the head.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Tough cookie. She smiles with pride, shivering.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FOREST. DAY
dialogues.text: Cam and the girls traipse through the woods, each one of searching for something on the ground. Sunlight filters through the hundred-year-old trees. The air is humming an buzzing. It feels like summer.  4. Suddenly Cam kneels by a rotten tree trunk. He gives a sh WHISTLE. His daughters run to him. The ground is covered with brig orange chanterelles. They are beautiful. They seem to glo in the shade of the tall trees. The girls are mesmerized.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I wish I had a gown that color. He holds out his hand and they each slap him five, laughi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chanterelles sizzle in a cast-iron pan. Cam stirs the gently, still wearing the jodhpurs but no jacket or shirt He also wears a battered old gray fedora with a small fre picked flower stuck in the band. A cigarette dangles from his lips. His gut hangs out. An attractive African-Americ woman in her mid-30s leans against the kitchen counter. S wears a housecoat. She looks tired. This is MAGGIE.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: That’s what education should be about. Hands-on, in the field. (calling loudly) You girls are fierce mushroom- hunters!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: They're in bed. Exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: It’s good for them to see the sunrise. They’re too stuck in their cozy little routines.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: They're ten and eight. A long loaded silence. Then:

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You haven't been taking your lithium. Cam picks up the cast iron pan and slams it down hard on burner. Maggie jumps and screams, startled. She turns and hurries away.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: God damn it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toys are scattered everywhere. A coffee table lies on its side. Cam holds a pack of cigarettes in each hand. His fa is enraged. Maggie rushes away from him. He follows her. The girls watch from the upstairs landing.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: My grandfather started the Harvard Forestry School -- I’m trying to bestow some of his legacy to my children -- and you’re hassling me about lithium!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m calling Dr. Wendell. Cam steps in front of her and smashes the phone out of th wall. He kicks a zebra skin drum across the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We live in this house -- He jabs his finger in her face.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You're just like my parents. You want to keep me doped! Depressed! Fat! Slow! You’d neuter me if you could!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (like speaking to a child) Your parents let us live in this house on the condition that you remain stable --

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: To hell with the house then! I’m not going to let my goddamn parents use it as a choke chain!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: How could you not take it?! How could you do that to us?! He suddenly drops to his knees, maudlin and melodramatic overcome with sincere emotion. He holds onto her housecoa

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: It kills me, Maggie. The girls and I had a beautiful morning. It was magical. That doesn’t happen when I take my lithium. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAM (cont'd) Don’t you understand? Please tell me you understand. He looks so desperate that she wants to say she understan But she can’t. He reacts with another 180-degree turn, ba to anger. He pounds the floor repeatedly.

dialogues.speaker: CAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know what? Forget it. I’m going to find someone who gets it. Who gets me! Cam turns and rips open the front door. He marches down t sloping lawn, swiftly and stiffly like a soldier. Maggie runs to the open door.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That’s just an excuse to get laid!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (without looking back) It’s a chance to be understood!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: By getting laid!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Boo hoo hoo! Poor bourgeois Maggie and her bourgeois monogamous fantasy!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DRIVEWAY. LATER
dialogues.text: Maggie, wearing a crochet dress and knee-high boots, thro garbage bags stuffed with clothes and toys into the trunk a pale blue Saab. The two little girls watch their franti mother. Amelia holds the entire “Little House on the Prairie” series; Faith hugs eight different Barbie Dolls. Cam appears at the end of the long driveway, riding his bicycle uphill. He is now wearing a red Speedo, thin-sole canvas tennis shoes, and a red bandana tied around his ne It is a ridiculous get-up. When he sees Maggie, he starts shouting.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey! Hold it, god damnit! Hold it!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (to her daughters) Get in, get in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is my car and those are my children! Feeble, Maggie, pretty fucking feeble! He pedals faster as Maggie pushes her daughters into the She dives in after them, pulls the door shut and locks al the doors.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAAB. SAME TIME
dialogues.text: Cam races up and crashes his bike hard into the car. He a the bike go sprawling. Maggie and the girls scream. Maggie slides into the driver’s seat and fumbles for the right key. She drops her key ring on the floor. Cam circles the car, gesturing wildly. He sounds faraway through the glass but he is roaring. The girls stare at h

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Goddamnit, Maggie! I am aman! I am aman! Men like to screw! That’s what we do!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Amelia, Faith. Cover your ears. They don’t. They watch in disbelief as Cam pounds his che and roars unto the skies:

dialogues.speaker: CAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s why we have balls! Then he rips open the hood and reaches into the engine. Maggie finds the right key, puts it in the ignition and t it. Nothing. She turns it again. Nothing. Cam slams the hood down and grins through the windshield. comes around to her driver’s side window. His eyes are bright and wet and insane. He holds the distributor cap.

dialogues.speaker: CAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m never going to let you go. I love you all too much. Both girls stare at him, completely still. Cam looks back them and sees their terrified faces looking out at him an his face changes. A profoundly sad expression comes over him. An expression of regret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. He staggers backwards, puts his hands in front of his fac and sinks to the driveway cross-legged. He doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAAB. LATER
dialogues.text: Maggie sits in the backseat, between the girls. Faith is her knees, braiding her mother’s hair. Amelia looks out t window. Cam hasn’t moved. His bare shoulders are beet red

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: He’s sitting on the gravel and all he’s wearing is a bathing suit.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Sweetie, your father is very sick right now. He’s not himself.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: He’s really sunburned.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Listen. Look at me. She does.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to tell your friends or teachers about any of this. We know your father’s a good person and he would never hurt us, but it’s hard for people to understand and it’s very sad. Okay? Okay? Amelia nods.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DRIVEWAY. DUSK
dialogues.text: Two policeman lay a blanket over Cam’s shoulders and help into the back of their police car. Cam is docile and does not resist. The girls watch from an upstairs bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MCLEAN HOSPITAL VISITING ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Maggie and the girls sit side-by-side on the couch of the visiting room of McLean Hospital.  9. Amelia is engrossed in “Watership Down.” Faith is making Barbie dolls kiss passionately and whispering. The room i pale green, filled with tranquil watercolors. A nurse holds the door open. Cam enters. He moves slowly and he is hunched over, bloated and slow. He has a shaggy beard. He wears an oversized stained t-shirt with an idio logo and sweatpants. His hands tremble.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA/FAITH
dialogues.text: Daddy! They run to him and hug him around the waist. He pats the heads with swollen hands. His speech is thick and slurred

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Little. Big Little. I loved your letters. I’m feeling much better. They are disturbed by his appearance.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: You are?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Your stomach is really big.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: That's the medication they put me on. Doesn’t hurt. Go on, hit it. He stands tall and sticks his lithium gut out. They shake their heads.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Come on. Pound on it. He slaps it again to show how hard it is. Amelia punches half-heartedly in the stomach. He tenses his muscles.

dialogues.speaker: CAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Harder. Let’s go. Amelia complies with a flurry of little fists. Cam shuffl away from her.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. Remember. Never do that when Harry Houdini’s not ready. That’s how they killed him. Cam sits down across from Maggie and indicates for the gi to climb into his lap. They do. He lights a cigarette wit unsteady hands and smiles at Maggie through the smoke.  10.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You're a sight for sore eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What happened to the clothes I brought you?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: There were too many buttons on shirts. And... (searching) ...latches on pants.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (ruefully) I feel great. Maggie looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You seemed better last week. Are they adjusting your medication?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Yeah, they're trying something new on me... (standing up) I want to sit down. Cam starts shuffling around the room again.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I want to sit down. I want to be home with my family.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: You will, Daddy! Cam smiles at them. Then, abruptly, he starts to sing, stiffly.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: “When Daddy comes marching home again, hurrah hurrah... We'll give him a hearty welcome then, hurrah hurrah... The men will cheer and the boys will shout, hurrah hurrah... the ladies they will all turn out, hurrah hurrah... And we'll all... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAM (cont'd) (pauses, re-sets) “When Daddy comes marching home again, hurrah hurrah... He holds his arms out. The girls go to him and sing along

dialogues.speaker: ALL FOUR
dialogues.text: “We'll give him a hearty welcome then, hurrah hurrah... The men will cheer and the boys will shout, hurrah hurrah, the ladies they will all turn out, hurrah hurrah... Their singing continues over:

dialogues.speaker: EXT. APARTMENT COMPLEX. DAY
dialogues.text: Two large brick apartment buildings face each other acros parking lot. It is an urban environment.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Maggie and the girls look around a vacant two-bedroom apartment. It is clean and bright and sunny. Maggie nods the SUPERINTENDENT. Amelia looks very worried. Maggie goes to the window and points, trying to be upbeat.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Look, girls. There’s a swimming pool. It’ll be open in the summer. Amelia looks out. In between the two matching apartment buildings is a pool enclosed by a chain link fence. Next the pool area is a concrete “park” area with metal picnic tables. Across from the building they are in is the other building, staring back at them.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Daddy loves swimming. Maggie doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie and the girls have moved in. The apartment is clea and spare. Marimekko prints cover simple Swedish furnitur The sunniest corner is full of hanging plants. Maggie has made it pleasant.  12. Maggie is in the kitchen cooking dinner. The girls sit at the dining room table. Amelia is doing h math homework. Faith wears an all-lavender outfit and she carving a flower design into the antique mahogany table w the pointy handle of a fork. They pepper Maggie with questions and complaints.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: The roof lights come in our window at night and it’s too bright. I can’t sleep. It’s bright as day.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Maybe I can make a curtain for your room.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Mommy, they’re huge security lights. Like you would see at a prison.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Amelia, I also wish we could've stayed out in the country, but there were no good jobs in Sudbury.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Your job here isn’t good.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m going to find a better one.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Why can’t Daddy live here with us?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I don’t like visiting him at the halfway house.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Your father is still recovering from his breakdown.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: He’s a way better cook than you.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Maggie sighs heavily.  13.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Girls, let’s have a little quiet. A few moments of quiet.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Amelia watches as Faith digs in to the table harder and w more determination.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Daddy told me they injected him with Thorazine at the hospital and it made him bite the insides of his cheeks until his mouth was filled with blood. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s still quiet time.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: What’s Thorazine? Maggie comes out with two bowls of pasta and sees what Fa has been doing. She drops the bowls down on the table and grabs Faith by the shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Faith! What are you doing? Why would you do that? Why would you do that?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: It’s a flower. It’s pretty. Maggie sinks into a dining room chair, lays her head on t table and sobs. After a moment, the girls take their past bowls and start eating in silence.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Now we're being quiet, Mommy.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Yeah, Mommy, now we’re being quiet.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: It is raining. Faith and Amelia, both wearing backpacks, walk down an urban sidewalk. They are five feet apart, no speaking. They come to a corner. Amelia goes straight and Faith goes right.  14.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ALLEY. DAY
dialogues.text: Amelia trudges alone down an alley.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DESOLATE PARK. DAY
dialogues.text: Amelia cuts through a public park.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VINYL-SIDED HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Amelia approaches a three-story house. She rings the doorbell. She is dripping wet. One of Cam’s HOUSEMATES answers the door. He has an unfriendly, suspicious manner and bad skin.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: My father... lives here?

dialogues.speaker: INT. SECOND-FLOOR HALLWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: Amelia passes a fidgety woman with a bowl haircut. She st and stares at the closed door to her father’s room. There a home-made poster taped to the door which reads: You say INDIVIDUAL RESPONSIBILITY, I say WE ARE NOT ALONE. Also taped to the door is a National Geographic picture o gorilla. She knocks.

dialogues.speaker: CAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes? She opens the door. Cam sits over the various parts of a camera, unshaven with a cigarette in his mouth. He wears jeans and a green sweatshirt that says “Vermont”. His roo is filled with moving boxes stacked floor to ceiling. He stands, surprised to see his bedraggled daughter.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Darling! Poor little draggletail. He tosses the cigarette into a Styrofoam coffee cup and p it on a table with many other old half-filled cups with cigarette butts in them. He kneels down to hug her.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I’m going to make you some soup. He picks her up in his arms and carries her down the stai  15.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALFWAY HOUSE KITCHEN. DAY
dialogues.text: Amelia's clothes hang over the hissing radiator, drying o Cam stirs soup on the stove. Amelia sits at the table wrapped in a big towel. Cam opens a tin of biscuits and arranges them on a plate.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: What’s my plan? My plan is... get a job. That’s number one. Amelia nods her approval.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I'll get out of this halfway house and get my own apartment. Then you girls can come for sleepovers and I’ll make crepes for breakfast and dinner. Amelia nods her approval.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: And then I’11l move back in with you and Faith and Mommy. That is, if Mommy will have me. He holds the plate of biscuits out to her. She takes one.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: I feel like Lucy visiting Mr. Tumnus. Cam smiles, pleased.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: That's the nicest thing anyone’s ever said to me.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Mommy says you have a drinking problem. Cam bristles, offended.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Most people I know drink far more than I do.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: I think if you could stop drinking and take your lithium then Mommy would let you come home.  16.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (sighing deeply) I don’t think Mommy loves me anymore.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: But she says she loves you!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Really? Does she say it a lot?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: She always says she loves you. But that it’s hard to live with you when you refuse to face up to your adult responsibilities.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (frowns ) Do you think Mommy should be confiding in you like this?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: The thing is I can see all this from Mommy's point of view. I certainly understand why she slept with Jake Beal after the Walden Pond incident. Sleeping with Will Bronson was pushing it, but I still forgive her.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: But Mommy says you slept with somebody in the hall closet during a party when I was eight months old. She says you started it.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (defensive) I was manic. I was high as a kite when I did that. I never had a prolonged affair like everybody else seems to do! Amelia looks down and reaches for another biscuit. Cam sighs, sorry and sad.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Do you still feel like Lucy visiting Mr. Tumnus?  17.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Not really. INT. MAGGIE’S DREARY OFFICE. DAY Maggie stands at a large metal filing cabinet, organizing color-coded files. A square-shaped woman in her 50s depos a tall stack of files next to Maggie’s head: CAROL.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: These too. The phone rings. Maggie tenses.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Tell your kids to stop calling. This is a job. Carol trundles away. Maggie answers, professionally.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Hello, Keller Brothers -- (quietly) Faith, is it important, sweetie? You can’t call so much. They don’t like it. No TV... Okay, one show -- two shows and a movie, but please don’t call again unless you have to. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. EVENING
dialogues.text: Cam makes dinner: crepes filled with creamed chicken and spinach. Faith sets the table. Amelia plays the piano. The front door key turns in the lock.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Mommy’s home! Maggie opens the door and walks in with a bag of grocerie Faith gestures to the table with a flourish. Maggie nods, impressed, and then she sees Cam in the kitchen and react surprised, but not unpleasantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie joins Cam in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Hello.  18.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Hello. Guess who showed up on my doorstep today? He nods toward Amelia. Maggie puts her groceries down.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: How did she get there?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Walked.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: All the way from school? He nods. They share a look of parental concern. Then:

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I think we should find a therapist for her to talk to.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Do you think that’s something your parents might pay for? Mine can’t help anymore.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I’1l ask them. Maggie smiles at him gratefully and unpacks the groceries They move around the tiny kitchen. In the living room, Amelia starts playing a jaunty version of “The Entertaine

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: She's getting good. (calling) That sounds great, Big Little! (to Maggie) How’s the job going?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh, the job. She hangs her head.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I graduated from Sarah Lawrence. I can’t believe I’m doing this. Maggie looks sad and tired. Cam puts his arm around her a Maggie leans into his shoulder. Amelia walks into the kitchen and puts her arms around both parents, joining th in this sweet moment. They smile down at her. Then Maggie deflates.  19.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I forgot the laundry --

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: We'll get it! She pushes her parents together and runs from the room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT BUILDING HALLWAY. MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: The apartment door slams. Amelia and Faith walk down the hall with a hamper. They look at each other hopefully.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT BUILDING STAIRS NEAR LAUNDRY ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Amelia and Faith walk away from the laundry room with the hamper full of clothes. Three children are playing cards the stairs in the hall. KIM, 10, and ALI, 8, are Korean sisters. Also with them is THURGOOD, 12, who is black and very tall, friendly and fey.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA/FAITH
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: I’m Kim. This is Ali. This is Thurgood. We live on the ninth floor.

dialogues.speaker: THURGOOD
dialogues.text: (with a floppy wave) Hey there.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: I’m Amelia and this is Faith.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: You guys go to Lincoln?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: No. We go to Peabody. Kim squints angrily.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Peabody is the best public school in the city. We’re not in the Peabody School district.  20. Thurgood puts his hand to his mouth, mock afraid.

dialogues.speaker: THURGOOD
dialogues.text: (sing song) Uh oh. Somebody’s telling a big fat fib!

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: If you live here, you’re supposed to go to Lincoln. A school that is totally one hundred percent terrible.

dialogues.speaker: THURGOOD
dialogues.text: Unless you like getting your ‘A’ kicked by Irish kids.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I don’t want to get my ‘A’ kicked.

dialogues.speaker: THURGOOD
dialogues.text: Honey, nobody does.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Well... we go to Peabody. As Amelia and Faith struggle up the stairs with their ham

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: You don’t get it. What you’re doing is illegal. And it’s not fair. It’s not at all fair. You guys are going to go to jail. Amelia and Faith hurry away. Faith looks back.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The family sits at the table, having finished the dinner made. Music plays on the record player.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: What if someone asks me where I live? I don’t want to lie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Peabody is the best public school in the city --  21.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: I don’t care. I don’t want to lie.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You're not lying, sweetheart. Your mother is lying. Maggie furrows her brow at him.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I don’t want to go to Lincoln! They said we’re going to get beat up.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, Faithie. I’11 teach you how to fight.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: What if my teacher finds out I’m lying?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Miss Kendricks loves you. You're her best student.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (wailing) They said we'd get our ‘A’ kicked by Irish kids!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You're not going to get your ‘A’ kicked --

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (riled up) -- you'll be kicking ‘A’!

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: If you want us to go to the Peabody School so bad, why didn’t we move into the Peabody School district?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: We can’t afford the Peabody School district. We’re lucky to have gotten a rent-controlled apartment.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: But Daddy’s family is so rich --  22.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (losing it) Yes, but we have no money! Can you girls understand that! We have no money! I send out my resume and I get nothing! I just spent my last twelve dollars! You want to be poor and get a bad education? The neighbor below bangs very angrily on the ceiling. The all sit in silence. Then:

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Seconds, anyone? Faith holds out her plate. Cam serves.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Cam, for this delicious dinner.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Could be like this every night... Maggie stiffens.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That would be nice, but I need a husband, not a wife.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I'd like to be a husband but my wife won’t let me.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Girls, go play in the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: But --

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Go! As they scurry out of the apartment:

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I’m lonely, Maggie. I don’t want to move to some shitty apartment, I want to come home!  23.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HALLWAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The girls listen at the door with concern as their parent continue to argue.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm lonely too, Cam! This, here, is lonely, but you have to show me that it’ll be different this time. Bohemia is over -- A neighbor across the hall opens the door and looks annoy

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Maggie lays out three Business School applications on the dining room table: Harvard, Columbia, Wharton.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: Cam is on a pay phone on Mass Ave. He is leaving an answering machine message. He wears a green polo shirt an madras shorts. He wears a Polaroid 250 around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Hi, Maggie. It’s me. It’s a beautiful day. I’m skulking around Harvard Square. Anybody home? Pick up if you’re there. He waits. No answer. He continues his message.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Just wanted to see...

dialogues.speaker: INT. RESTAURANT PHONE BOOTH. DIFFERENT DAY
dialogues.text: Cam stands at a restaurant pay phone, leaving another message. He wears a battered corduroy sportcoat.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: ..»-what you and the girls are up to. Thought we could go sailing. I think Eliot Perkins would let me borrow his sailboat...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. DIFFERENT DAY
dialogues.text: Cam is at a different pay phone, leaving another message. wears a three-piece suit. He wears the Polaroid 250.  24.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: ...Or “Bringing up Baby” is playing at the Orson Welles and there’s also a Buster Keaton festival -- A loud BEEP. The machine hangs up on him. Cam hangs up th phone and walks out alone into the bustling street.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SCHOOL HALLWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: Amelia sits on a bench outside the Principal's Office, hugging her backpack, trying not to cry. Maggie exits the Principal's Office and sits down next to Amelia.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (lightly) He said we're not in the Peabody School district so you and Faith have to go to Lincoln. Amelia's face crumples.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Mommy. Maggie hugs Amelia to her.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Don’t apologize to me. Please don't apologize to me --

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: He asked where we lived and I wasn’t sure what to say --

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You did the right thing. I never wanted you to lie.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: He said it was illegal what we were doing.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I guess I wasn’t thinking of it that way. I just wanted you to go to the best school. Maggie sits back and wipes at Amelia’s tears.  25.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: What if Faith gets beat up and it’s all because of me?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about Faith. Faith bites. Amelia laughs, then:

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: I love my teacher.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: And she loves you. She stopped me in the hall and told me... (her voice breaks) She was so sorry. And she would miss you very much. Amelia nods and leans against her mother.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Cam enters with two pillowcases stuffed with clothes. Two sleeping bags sit on the sofa. As Cam picks up a teddy be and stuffs it in one of the pillowcases:

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Sleeping bags, pajamas, stuffed animals, books, changes of clothes, what am I forgetting?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Toothbrushes? Maggie enters from the kitchen with a tray. On it is a teapot and tea cups and buttered toast on a plate. She pu it on the table and pours it out, handing him a cup.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I bought toothbrushes they can keep at my apartment. And I took two big cardboard boxes and set them up like little beds. They’re going to flip.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: They're so excited.  26.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: And during the day they can turn them over and use them as puppet theaters.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You're going to have fun.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Now that I have my own place, Maggie, I’d be happy to pick them up any day and have them stay over. There’s room for you too... Beat. Maggie doesn’t reciprocate.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Just kidding. Not until you’re ready.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Cam, I got into business school. Cam reacts, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Maggie Stuart, you are some punkins. I wish I had some of that bourgeois midwestern can-do.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I got a scholarship. To Columbia. Cam is thrown.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Wait. You can’t take the girls to New York.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No. I can’t even afford a studio apartment in New York. Jenny said her mother has a small room she can rent me.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: So what about the girls?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Here’s my proposal. I can get my degree in eighteen months if I do the summer session. So I go to New York. You move in here and take care of the girls.  27. He looks at her for a long beat. Then:

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: «--Me? He takes out a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes. You. You miss them. And they miss you so much. It’s just eighteen months. When I get my MBA, I'll get a job in Boston and move back in here. (gripping his arm) I know it sounds crazy, Cam, but you can do it. I know you can. Cam walks away from her, considering.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I suppose it might be good for me to have a purpose --

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: A routine. The doctor thinks that’s exactly what you need.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Yes. A routine. Getting meals on the table. Taking them to school every morning, putting them to bed every night, making sure they brush their hair and their teeth... the laundry. He looks exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: That sounds like a lot.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It is a lot. But we’re sinking deeper and deeper into a hole and I have to do something.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: The new school does feel a bit like a reformatory.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It’s grim. You and I went to good schools, we had piano lessons --  Cam looks She nods. 28.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I never had any lessons.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: But you learned how to fence and ski and sail and speak French...

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: But I never took lessons. My family taught me those things.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: The point is we both got a good education. And I want that for our children.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Well, I want that too. But eighteen months is a lot of routine.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You can do it.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I can?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I will come back every weekend and help you. at her.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Every weekend? And stay here with us?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: So it would be like we were a family again? Cam looks off into the distance, a determined look on his face. He feels the importance of his mission.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I am their father, after all.  29.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RESTAURANT. DAY
dialogues.text: Maggie sits across from MURRAY and PAULINE STUART, Cam’s parents. Murray wears a corduroy jacket with a pipe tucke into the pocket. Pauline wears a red turtleneck with a large, elaborate jade necklace over it.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: I'm afraid we need to intervene on our son’s behalf and say: no. He’s just not up to the task.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I know he can do it.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: And what if he can’t? It’s a recipe for disaster. Reveal that Cam is also at the table. He takes umbrage at his father’s remark as he lights his mother’s cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You don’t seem to think I can do anything.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: We just don’t want you to tax yourself, darling boy.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: We met with Dr. Wendell. He said Cam has made an excellent recovery from his breakdown and he felt he could do this.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: He thinks I need more responsibility, not less. Murray looks mystified.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: But you’re a man. Even if you could do it, why would you want to?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He loves to cook. He loves to tell stories and play games. He's a good father. I would never ask him if I didn’t believe he could do it. Cam smiles at her gratefully. He puts his hand on hers.  30.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: We believe in him too, but what if he has a breakdown?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He won’t. Because we’re all going to support him and make sure he takes his lithium. I/’11 check in every day on the phone and I'll be there on the weekends.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: That sounds exhausting.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Is this because of Feminism?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: We're living at the poverty level. The girls are at a terrible school.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Our children went to the best schools and I'll tell you, it didn’t add up to much.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: (turning on him) Our children are delightful!

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Absolutely. But not one of them is self-supporting.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: Well, Murray, lest you forget: neither are we. Annoyed, Murray pulls the pipe out of his pocket and star to pack it.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I think what Maggie is doing is quite admirable.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: I agree. Very commendable.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: But how did it get to this? I thought Gaga was paying the rent on your little apartment.  31.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: She is.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: It isn’t enough?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: (to Murray) Don’t we have some crystal or some silver we could sell?

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: That won’t even pay for this meal.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: (forcefully) No no no. Maggie Stuart, you cannot leave your family.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Pauline, I’m desperate. Utterly and completely desperate. We have no money. Pauline looks like she just ate something terrible.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: I hate talking about “money!” Pauline always says the word “money” with extreme distast

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Then let’s drop it.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: (leaning in) I wish we could help but we're barely getting by on the dollops of cash Gaga doles out to us...

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Pauline, please! Murray turns his back on the table and aggressively puffs his pipe. This is uncomfortable for him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Cam is a trust fund baby with no trust fund. My parents have done all they can. One of us is going to have to earn a living.  32. Pauline looks very sad. She pats Maggie’s hand with genui emotion.

dialogues.speaker: PAULINE
dialogues.text: Oh, my dear, it all just sounds so dreary!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PARKING LOT. DAY
dialogues.text: Cam, wearing jade swimming trunks and a bright green shir is organizing Maggie's suitcases in the back of a small U Haul. A nervous, skinny man in his 40s looks on, biting h fingernails. He is PETER.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Why does he keep re-arranging everything? It was fine before. We need to go, Maggie. We’re heading into miserable traffic. Maggie nods. Peter gets into the passenger seat. Cam look toward him suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Who is this wimp?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Carol Webber’s cousin. He’s moving to New York to live with his mother. I’m lucky he’s splitting the cost of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: He’s making you drive? Cam seems unconvinced. Maggie hugs Amelia and Faith and tries to be upbeat.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You can call me anytime day or night. And I’m going to come home the weekend after next, so don’t be too sad because you’re going to see me before you know it. They nod. Faith wipes away her tears. Amelia is stone- faced.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Amelia, you have to brush your hair. Faith, will you make sure your sister brushes her hair?  33. Faith nods. Amelia shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You are going to have a lot of fun with Daddy. Peter honks the horn. Cam reacts angrily.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Hey! Maggie stands quickly.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Cam --

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (re: Peter) You're saying goodbye to your daughters! What kind of a cold- hearted S.0O.B. honks the horn?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Please. I’m about to spend five hours in very close quarters. Cam sighs and nods. Then:

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Cam, thank you. I know this is big. Cam wears a stoic expression.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I just wish I hadn’t dressed like a big green bug. Maggie laughs. He wraps her up in a big hug. Then the hor honks again.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Go. Seriously. Or I’m going to kick the living shit out of this guy. Maggie gets into the driver's seat.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I love you. I love you girls!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: We love you too.  34. The truck starts up. It pulls out into the street. They a stand waving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie wipes a tear away. Peter is oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: We'll have to make a lot of stops, I have a very small bladder -- Suddenly Maggie is startled to see Cam running full-speed alongside the truck.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Maggie! Take the Wilbur Cross Parkway! Maggie is stuck moving forward in the flow of traffic. Sh doesn’t know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: The what?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Remember, Maggie? We were going to Tom and Linda’s wedding and we thought we’d be late but I took the back roads and we made it in the nick of time? The Wilbur Cross Parkway! She's looking for a place to pull over. People behind her are honking now.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know if I remember....

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (shouting) At New Haven, shoot across 34 West to the Wilbur Cross! It becomes the Merritt Parkway!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck keeps moving and Cam can’t keep up. He shouts after them.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You can avoid Bridgeport and the trees are twice as green!  35. Cam lights a cigarette. He stares after the truck as it disappears from view.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PARKING LOT. DAY
dialogues.text: Cam walks back to his daughters who are still standing on sidewalk where he left them. Faith is crying. Amelia is n letting herself. He picks Faith up and she puts her head his shoulder. As they walk toward the apartment building:

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Who wants ice cream for lunch?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PARK. DAY
dialogues.text: The girls still look really sad while they eat their ice cream cones. Cam watches them with concern.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Want to see a movie? They shake their heads.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: We could drive out to Plum Island and look for sea glass? They shake their heads.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: We could go to the Museum of Fine Arts and look at Great Grandpapa’s portrait.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Why is his portrait hanging at the museum?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Because a very important artist named John Singer Sargent painted it.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (indignant) “Why?” Don’t you know who we are?  36.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BEACON HILL. DAY
dialogues.text: Cam and the girls are in his Fiat. The car is filled with trash: food wrappers, used napkins, empty containers, ora peels, mail. They are parked outside a large freestanding mansion on Beacon Hill.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: That’s where your great-grandmother grew up.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: In that whole house?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: The whole thing. It’s the grandest house on Beacon Hill. Designed by Bulfinch, a very famous architect.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: How did they get so rich?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Railroads. Your great-great- grandfather was once the richest man in Boston.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: So how come we’re so poor?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: ...-Well, all that money was put into a trust which is controlled by your great-grandmother. And she decides when to give who what. And... it’s hard to explain. The girls stare at the house in awe.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You want to see the inside? They look excited and confused.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Are we allowed?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: You can’t just walk up and knock on people’s doors.  37.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (tickled by her ignorance) Sweetheart... this is Boston. They're practically expecting us.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ENTRY HALL. DAY
dialogues.text: The girls look around the grand entry hall, amazed. Cam h a hand on each of their shoulders. A MAID comes in.

dialogues.speaker: MAID
dialogues.text: Mr. Fabrini will be out ina minute.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (to girls) On the second floor are the parlors where they would have huge fancy dress balls...they would lay thick canvas down to protect the wooden floors and it looked like snow... A man in his mid-40s comes out of a study. This is MR. FABRINI. He wears a business suit. He seems annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: MR. FABRINI
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Hello. My name is Cam Stuart. My great-grandmother grew up in this house and I was wondering if I could show it to my daughters. It’s an important part of their family history.

dialogues.speaker: MR. FABRINI
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Mr. Stuart. But this is my home. I don’t give tours. The girls are mortified. They both start for the door, bu Cam holds them in place. He is defiant.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: This house was in my family for more than five generations. My great-great grandfather was born in this house on Boxing Day in 1842.

dialogues.speaker: MR. FABRINI
dialogues.text: And would your great-great- grandfather give tours to anyone who came along?  38.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Certainly. If they had a personal connection going back more than five generations.

dialogues.speaker: MR. FABRINI
dialogues.text: Then he’s a better man than me.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (pointed) “Better man than I.” The girls wince.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FIAT. MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Cam drives much too fast down Storrow Drive, weaving in a out of traffic. Everyone is shouting.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: We're going back there again! I’m going back every day till he shows you that house!

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Slow down!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Our family lived there for more than a century for chrissake!

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: But it’s his house now and he doesn’t want to show it to you!

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: That was so embarrassing!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t be embarrassed! He should be embarrassed!

dialogues.speaker: FAITH/AMELIA
dialogues.text: No! You should be embarrassed! Cam reacts as if they are speaking a foreign language.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Me? I’m not embarrassed! I’m the eldest son of the eldest son of the richest man in the world!  39.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ELEVATOR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The family rides the elevator in silence. All three of th look furious.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The apartment is filled with boxes. Amelia is on the kitc phone. Faith is on the phone in the living room. They are both unhappy, talking low, as Cam lurks about.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: We want you to come home.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I‘1l be home in twelve days...

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: We want you to come home right now.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is a big adjustment --

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Why aren’t you coming home this Friday? You said you’d come home every single weekend. That’s what you said. INT. MAGGIE’S NEW YORK ROOM. SAME TIME Maggie stands in a grim little room with a bed and a desk a bright overhead light. Her suitcases surround her. You can hear loud traffic noise.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I have registration and orientation -- next weekend is really not that far away...

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. MORNING
dialogues.text: Cam is snoring on the couch still wearing the bright gree shirt and jade swimming trunks. The TV is on. Faith stand over him, near tears, in her nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Daddy, wake up. Daddy. We slept too long and we’re going to be late for school.  40. Cam opens his eyes and blinks at her, disoriented.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY OUTSIDE ELEVATOR. DAY
dialogues.text: A disheveled Cam races down the hall and puts his hand on door of the elevator to keep it from closing. In his othe hand he has a box of cereal.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Girls! Let’s move it! On the elevator is an attractive woman professionally dressed. This is BECCA. She wears a turtleneck sweater an big brown glasses. She smiles at Cam. He smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You're Maggie’s friend. I’m Cam.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Becca. Kyle’s mother. Faith runs onto the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I hate being late for school.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, bunchkin. You won’t be late. Cam holds out the box of cereal. Faith reaches in, grabs handful, stuffs it in her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (calling) Amelia! Let’s go!

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I just have to say: my ex-husband would never do what you’re doing. I think it is so evolved. Cam puffs up.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You do? Tousled Amelia runs onto the elevator. Cam steps on.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Most men would be extremely emasculated having their wife go off to be the breadwinner.  41.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (deflates) Oh. Thanks. The elevator doors close.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: Cam runs a red light at the intersection of Huron Ave and Garden Street. The girls scream.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SCHOOL. DAY
dialogues.text: He pulls up with a screech in front of the school. The gi tumble out. As they sprint off:

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You want me to pick you up after school?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA/FAITH
dialogues.text: No! He watches the girls run up the deserted steps of the sch

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I love you!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PARKING LOT. DAY
dialogues.text: Cam has the hood of his car open. The girls walk up, wear their backpacks, not talking to each other.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You girls want to learn how to change an oil filter? It’s pretty straightforward --

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA/FAITH
dialogues.text: No./Not really.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Just don’t be helpless. He shuts the hood. A woman in her mid-50s is taking many grocery bags out of her car. This is RUTH-ANN MCKAY.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Who's that?  42.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Ruth-Ann.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Please don’t introduce yourself.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Because you talk too much and nobody wants to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I'm just being friendly. Don’t you want to know your neighbors? We live in a world with other people. He approaches Ruth-Ann. The girls follow.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH-ANN
dialogues.text: Hello girls.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA/FAITH
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Hi, Cam Stuart -- Ruth-Ann shakes hands warmly.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH-ANN
dialogues.text: Yes, Maggie told me. Welcome to 205. Ruth-Ann McKay.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Can we help you with your bags?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH-ANN
dialogues.text: (grateful) Are you kidding? As they pick up the bags:

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: See, girls? People appreciate a little kindness. That’s all I’m talking about.  43.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT HALLWAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cam carries three bags and the girls each struggle to car one down the hall to Ruth-Ann’s apartment. She unlocks he door and starts taking the bags from them.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Do you need us to help you put them away?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH-ANN
dialogues.text: No, this is fine. Just put the bags down.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Are you sure? We’re happy to do it.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH-ANN
dialogues.text: No, this has been so helpful. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You need anything moved? A desk or something like that?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH-ANN
dialogues.text: No I’m happy with where my desk is... She starts to close the door.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Sometimes mixing up an arrangement freshens a space --

dialogues.speaker: RUTH-ANN
dialogues.text: No, thank you. I have to start dinner. So if you’1l excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You need anything chopped? An onion?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH-ANN
dialogues.text: No. I’m not using onions tonight. She closes the door in his face.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: What is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: You made her slam the door in your face.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (oblivious ) She had to go cook dinner.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: She had to get rid of you!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Get off my case! I’m just being a good neighbor!

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: You're an annoying neighbor. People are going to see you and run in the other direction!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: No, they’re going to run toward me! Because I’m going to make sure they know that I’m the kind of guy who’s willing to move heavy furniture! Or clean out a storage locker! (yelling) Because I’m a good neighbor! He storms off down the hallway. Ten strides later.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: This is bullshit! He goes into the stairwell and slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING AREA. NIGHT
dialogues.text: They sit at the dining table, eating in angry silence. Th Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I learned to cook this on a Norwegian steamship headed down the Amazon.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: When did you do that?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Summer after I got kicked out of Harvard.  45.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: I thought you got kicked out of Exeter.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I got kicked out of both. For very different reasons... The girls’ interest is piqued. INT. GIRLS’ BEDROOM. NIGHT Cam sits in the reading chair. The girls are in their bed listening intently to their father’s story. Faith has curlers in her hair and a net over them.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I was on my way to my Ec 10 exam and I hear this bag-pipe music so I follow the sound into The Square and a street musician is playing Scottish ballads and he’s got his hat out. People are walking by and putting money in it and I think that's a good idea. So I put my hat out and sit next to him and I start singing along in my best Scottish brogue and he tells me to scram.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Because he didn’t ask you to sing and he wants to make all the money.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Exactly. Well, we exchanged a few words and then...the bastard jumped me! This scrawny little guy and he jumped me! We got into a major brawl on top of the bag pipes and I got so excited I shit my pants.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA/FAITH
dialogues.text: Ew! Cam laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Needless to say, I didn’t make the exam.  46.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: And they kicked you out for missing one exam?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Well... then the next semester I registered for seventy-five courses. He chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: That’s when they determined I might not be Harvard material.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Both girls are asleep, breathing steadily. The clock tick Cam gets up from his chair and turns out the light.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cam walks into the living room of the apartment, which is full of all his boxes. He stares at them. Cam opens a box. It is filled with magazines, pieces of paper, phone books, tools, cords. It is completely disorganized. He blinks at it. It fills him with despair.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dirty dishes are piled in the sink and all over the count Cam stares at it in despair.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: The laundry hamper is overflowing, dirty clothes piled halfway up the wall. Cam stares at it in despair.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FRONT DOOR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cam grabs his coat and scarf from the coat-stand.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (loudly) Girls, I’m going out for a couple of hours. You get some good rest. I‘1l be back before midnight... No answer from the sleeping girls.  47.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: ...Or after midnight. Love you! He opens the door, closes it quietly behind him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PARKING LOT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cam steps out into the cool air. He takes a deep breath, lights a cigarette, and heads out into the night.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DIVE BAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A bar full of aging professors, shaggy poets and intense poetesses. Cam sits at the bar, drinking a can of beer. He has an animated conversation with two friends. One wears a bow-t horn-rimmed glasses and a tweed jacket; the other wears a grimy coat and ragged hat. The homeless-looking friend laughs, revealing no front teeth. Cam gestures to the bartender, indicating another round.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT BUILDING HALLWAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cam, drunk and smoking, walks down the long hall to the corner apartment. He takes out his keys and opens the doo But it stops; the chain-lock has been fastened. All the lights in the apartment are on.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (pissed off) Oh, shit. He knocks.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Unchain the door, please. Amelia comes running from the living room, crazy-haired, wielding a baseball bat.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Where did you go?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Unchain the fucking door.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: We woke up and you were gone. Faith was really scared.  48. Cam grows more irritated.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Don’t use the chain. Anyone who really wants to come in won’t be stopped by this dinky chain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she unchains it:

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: It stopped you. As he enters:

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I didn’t really want to come in.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cam stumbles in and Amelia holds up the telephone receive triumphant.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Mommy’s on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Thank you. Thanks a lot. He reluctantly takes the telephone from her. She walks do the hall to her bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (to phone) Hello. (beat) Everything's fine, Maggie. Nobody is hurt. (beat) I told them I was going out, but they were sleeping! Should I wake them up every time I want to go out? INT. GIRLS’ BEDROOM. NIGHT Amelia sits down on the bed next to Faith.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: She's going to know he’s doing a bad job.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: He’s drunk.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Do you think it’s good for Mommy to know that? Amelia shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: She's coming home a week early. Faith gasps with excitement and hugs her sister tight.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BATHROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cam opens the medicine chest and takes out his enormous bottle of lithium. He stares at it for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SCHOOL. DAY
dialogues.text: The Fiat pulls up in front of the school. Children are filing in. The girls jump out of the car. Before Amelia slams the door:

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Remember, girls. Mommy’s coming Friday. Let’s make the apartment nice for her.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: You have to unpack your boxes.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (lighting a cigarette) I'm just saying, we all need to pitch in -- Both girls look bratty and pissed-off.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: But they’re your boxes...

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: We don’t know what to do with them...

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: We don’t ask you to clean up our room... Cam cannot handle the onslaught of attitude.  50.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Fuck it, forget it. Have a nice fucking day. Cam puts the Fiat in gear and zooms off, way too fast. Th girls watch him go, stunned and self-conscious, knowing t the other kids heard.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Cam looks at all the boxes. The place is a disaster. He goes to the window and looks out. It is a beautiful day. Cam sighs.

dialogues.speaker: THE RECORD PLAYER
dialogues.text: Cam drops the needle on Olatunje’s Drums of Passion. A he rhythmic beat fills the room as he opens up the first box pulls out a rusted old machete.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. LATER
dialogues.text: The girls enter the apartment. They can’t believe their eyes. It is spic and span. A large new bookshelf lines th front hall. They jump up and down like crazy.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH/AMELIA
dialogues.text: Daddy! Daddy! Daddy! Daddy! Cam enters from his bedroom. He wears a grimy, oil-staine jumpsuit. The girls throw themselves into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Pretty good, right?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: It’s beautiful. We love it!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Just don’t look in my bedroom. The girls hurry to his bedroom.  51.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAM'S BEDROOM. MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Cam’s room looks like a garage. Large industrial metal shelves house paint-thinner, spray paint cans, motor oil, etc. Stacks of mail and magazines cover the desk and ther are clothes all over the bed. Amelia points at the bed.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Is that a machete?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: We'll keep this door closed... She closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Spirits are high. Amelia clears the dining room table. Faith washes the dishes and Cam dries and puts the dishes away. They sing a World War II marching song.

dialogues.speaker: ALL THREE
dialogues.text: Hitler! Has only got one ball...Goering! Has two but very small...Himmler! Has something sim'lar...But Josef Goebels has no balls at all...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TRAIN STATION. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cam and the girls stand on the platform as the train pull to the Station. Cam is trying to untangle some of the massive snarls in Amelia's hair. Maggie gets off at the f end. The girls take off, running for her. Maggie drops her suitcase and drops to her knees and hold them tight. Cam walks toward them, smiling. He holds a bunch of orange gerberas. She accepts them and kisses him the cheek. She kisses both girls on the head. He picks up her suitcase and they walk down the platform. The girls skip alongside, holding their mother’s hand, ha to be all together.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. DAY
dialogues.text: The family bustles into the apartment. Maggie stops dead when she sees how cozy and warm it is. She looks at them with amazement. The girls are gleeful.  52.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Who built these shelves?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Daddy. Cam looks modest but he is bursting with pride.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: They're just shelves.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PARK. DAY
dialogues.text: Faith and Amelia play on the monkey bars. Cam and Maggie on a bench. Maggie looks happy.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It was hard to come this weekend. I’m so glad I did. I think this is just what you needed, Cam! I think this is going to be a great thing for us. He smiles at her and takes her hand. She smiles back at h They sit holding hands as they watch the girls play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cam lays out a bunch of newspaper on the living room floo and goes to work, taking apart an old phone. He walks awa from the tools and parts of the disassembled phone and it never moves.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The girls come in with a large hamper of laundry. They du it on the sofa and start folding it, but then they run of and it stays where it is.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The family sits in the living room eating dinner in front the television. A large roll of paper towels that is sitt on the coffee table is knocked over and rolls to the floo leaving a long trail of paper towel. Nobody picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cam lies on the sofa, drinking a beer and watching television. His head rests on the pile of clean laundry. Amelia and Faith roller skate around the room.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The phone parts have been pushed under the piano bench to make room for Cam’s bicycle, which stands upside down as fixes the brake mechanism. He puts his glass down on top the piano, in front of a large model ship. The top of the piano is now filled with dirty glasses, beer cans and emp yogurt containers with spoons sticking out of them.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Cam sits down in his armchair and starts taping wide silv duct tape over a large tear in the arm. Pull back on the living room. Nothing has been picked up put away. It is a disaster.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Faith stares miserably at the stack of dirty dishes in th kitchen sink.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cam sits in his armchair. The TV is on. He is trying to brush the snarls out of Amelia’s hair.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Ow! Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: ow!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: This is what happens when you don’t brush your hair for two weeks. Faith marches out of the kitchen, furious.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Daddy, if you’re not going to do the dishes, then I’m doing them. Cam blinks at her. It is an odd threat. He shrugs.  54.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Okay. Faith marches into the kitchen. A cupboard opens and slam shut. He turns his attention back to Amelia’s hair.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: You're hurting me! I’11 do it! She turns and rips the brush from his hand.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Fine. You do it. Amelia stomps away to the bedroom. Seconds later Faith marches back to the living room with a sponge held betwee two fingers.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Where are the sponges? Cam becomes immediately stern.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with that sponge?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: It smells!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Then don’t smell it!

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: My hands stink just from touching it!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: That’s because someone left it soaking in the dishwater! I keep telling you girls, it needs to be rinsed and squeezed when you’re through with it!

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You brought it from your old apartment! It’s probably five years old! It’s disgusting!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: We are not the kind of people who throw perfectly useful things away!

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You won’t throw anything away!  55.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: That is a perfectly good sponge with plenty of life left in it! Faith throws the sponge at him.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Fine! Then you do the dishes!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Fine! I will! With this sponge! Faith runs away. The downstairs neighbor pounds on the ceiling. Cam angrily pounds back.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Maggie, wearing her coat and holding her suitcase, stares with dismay at the wreckage of the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: We lost some momentum, but we’1ll get it back. (beat) I did get a new sponge. (pointed, to the girls) Even though I washed the old one with soap and it smelled fine.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Maggie, wearing yellow rubber gloves and her hair tied ba cleans furiously. Cam and the girls make piles.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Amelia helps her mother make her bed on the sofa. Faith practices her pirouettes.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Faith and I thought of the perfect job for Daddy. A crepe cart in Harvard Square. Like they have in Paris. Maggie and Cam look at each other, amused.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You do make the best crepes.  56.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: And I do love standing outside in January, freezing my ass off for pennies. Maggie laughs.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: We’re working on the menu.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I like chocolate and coconut.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: We have that! She does a dramatic pirouette. Her parents laugh.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: It is late. Maggie sits up in her bed on the sofa, sewing button on a little girl’s sweater. Cam sits at the other of the sofa. The girls have gone to bed. Cam is feeling sorry for himself.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: .--and the building is packed with single mothers who are always checking in with each other and getting together for coffee but do any of them ever ask how I’m doing? Do they ever invite me for coffee? I’m pretty sure they all got together for wine and cheese two nights ago. Maggie has to bite her lip to keep from laughing.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, it’s not funny.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (smiling) It is funny. It’s pathetic. I'ma pathetic whiner. Which is probably why they don’t invite me.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: They’re leery of men, that’s all. Especially married men with children.  57.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I’m not exactly a married man. (beat) Am I?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Well. We’re a family. Cam slides his hand up her leg. She shifts away.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: So is this really how we’re going to do it? You come every weekend and take up residence on the sofa?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: For now.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Come on, Maggie. We haven’t slept together since before my breakdown-- He leans forward and kisses her, but after a moment she r off the sofa and moves away from him. He chases after her playful, flirting.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know what will happen, Cam. I just want to get through this period. Can’t we see how it goes? As he attempts to unbutton her top:

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: And what happens at the end? You move back in here and what happens to us? Where do I go?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I want you to be the person we all know you can be. It will take steady, sustained effort. You can do it, Cam. If you want to do it. He puts his hand on her breast.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Sexy, sexy answer. She laughs at his unrelenting flirtation.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Honest, honest answer.  58.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: So what is this? Some big test?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Don’t think of it like that. You hate tests --

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Not if this was on the test... He kisses her. This time she kisses him back.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT HALLWAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The girls stand outside the closed door to Cam’s bedroom, listening and whispering to each other.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Are they having sex?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: I think maybe. The girls celebrate silently. Then they hear raised voice

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Cam. I just can’t make promises right now --

dialogues.speaker: CAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What a bunch of baloney. You must think I’m the biggest sucker on the planet. The girls scurry into their room as Cam’s bedroom door is ripped open. Cam walks out, pulling his shirt on. He grab his coat. He exits. Maggie runs after him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Are you taking your lithium?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Oh, shit. Lithium doesn’t stop you from feeling lonely and unappreciated. Enjoy your sofa. The front door slams.  59.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Maggie lies on her bed on the sofa. Amelia walks up to he Maggie lifts the covers and Amelia gets under the blanket next to her mother.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: When you and Daddy met at WGBH, was he the way he is now?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (delicately) In some ways. He was funny. Compassionate. He knew everything about the outdoors. He had a job, which was good for him. He was a terrific lighting designer. But in the end, it was too much pressure... I didn’t understand about the manic-depression. Besides, everyone was having nervous breakdowns in the 60s, so I didn’t realize what a big deal it was.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: You're probably sorry you married him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No. Never. Amelia snuggles in closer.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: You know, he’s not usually so angry like he just was. We yell at him way more than he yells at us. This information is not comforting to Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. DAY
