dialogues.text: A cold winter day in a run-down part of Somerville, Massachusetts. Cam leans over the engine of a dented and rusty Plymouth Valiant, gunmetal gray with white patches. He wears a gri green parka with a gray three-piece suit poking out underneath. He wears nice leather shoes. A cigarette hang out of his mouth. His hair is combed. He shuts the hood.  60. Amelia and Faith watch apprehensively. Amelia wears a par over white tights. Her snarly hair is pulled back in two barrettes. Faith wears a long wool coat and has her hair neatly combed under a velvet headband. Cam crosses to the driver’s side, gets in and turns the c on, revs the engine. CHRIS, the unfriendly man selling th car, doesn’t even try to give a spiel.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Like I said in the ad, it runs. Cam looks around the interior of the car.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: There’s been some wear and tear on the seats. A large flap of vinyl hangs down revealing the foam underneath. In the front and the back.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Get in, girls, see what you think. Chris opens the back door and the unhappy girls start to climb in.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: There’s no floor!

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: It’s a little rusted. Don’t step on it. Amelia and Faith look at each other, sinking. They slide onto the backseat without stepping on the floor. Cam leans through the back door and looks at the floor we which is a rusty hole with ragged rusted edges.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: No floor? That’s dangerous. I have two small children. I'11 give you three hundred and you deal with the Fiat. He points to the Fiat which now has a broken driver side window that’s been taped up with plastic and duct tape.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALIANT. DAY
dialogues.text: As the Valiant pulls away, Amelia kneels on the backseat waves out the back window.  61.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Fiat! Goodbye, Fiat! Cam honks the horn in rapid succession for a cheerful, triumphant goodbye. They drive out into the street. Faith sits down and opens a “Harper’s Bazaar” but Amelia stays kneeling on the seat, looking out the back window. Her ey fill with tears.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Daddy, Amelia's crying.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: You always cry. Faith looks out the window, an angry expression on her fa

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Not anymore. I vowed never to cry again. Cam looks in the rear-view mirror with concern.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: My little Stoic? What’s wrong, darling? Ma petite pamplemousse? The tears roll down Amelia’s face and she can’t wipe them away fast enough.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: It’s just... What’s going to happen to the Fiat? Nobody’s going to want it.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I thought you were crying because this car sucks. Amelia shakes her head and says in a small voice:

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: That car sucked too. She watches as the Fiat gets smaller and smaller and then they turn a corner and it’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALIANT. DAY
dialogues.text: The girls lie across the backseat, leaning against either door, huddled beneath an old army blanket. They wear hats  62. Faith has the “Harper's Bazaar” magazine on her chest and Amelia holds a book called “Turning Your Dream Into A Sma Business”. They are both mesmerized at the sight of the highway rush by through the rusty holes in the floor.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WESTON ESTATE. DAY
dialogues.text: The Valiant turns onto a long driveway and drives past an enormous lawn and a large weeping willow and an unattache four car garage and parks in the circle in front of the house, behind a maroon Bentley.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: A regal old lady sits at the head of a long mahogany tabl little silver bell by her water glass. She is 92 and of another era, extremely patrician. She wears a long-sleeve black dress, pearls and a blonde wig that looks like hair swirled into a bun. This is GAGA. Cam is at the foot and the girls are in the middle. The table could sit twelve. A BUTLER brings around a silver bowl of mashed potatoes. Faith spoons a huge amount onto her plate next to the roa beef and the peas. The butler continues around the table.

dialogues.speaker: GAGA
dialogues.text: I propose a game of crazy eights after lunch.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: GAGA
dialogues.text: We don’t say ‘yeah,’ dear. We say ‘yes.’

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Thank you, Gaga. Their mother keeps fighting that battle.

dialogues.speaker: GAGA
dialogues.text: And how is their mother?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: She’s well. She’s been home every weekend. But she has finals so she stayed in New York to study. We’re muddling through without her. (to the butler) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAM (cont'd) Tell Betty the roast beef is divine. The butler nods silently and disappears to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: GAGA
dialogues.text: Do you girls think it’s unusual that your mother is in New York?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: She wants to have more career opportunities.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Mommy says women can do anything.

dialogues.speaker: GAGA
dialogues.text: She's quite a “striver,” isn’t she? That hangs in the air for the moment.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: We prefer the word “fighter.”

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (pointing) Is that a painting of Grandma Paulie when she was little?

dialogues.speaker: GAGA
dialogues.text: Yes. And it’s pronounced (very patrician) ‘Paulie.’

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Polly.

dialogues.speaker: GAGA
dialogues.text: Paulie.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (trying hard) Polly. Polly.

dialogues.speaker: GAGA
dialogues.text: She’s not a parrot!

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Polly. Amelia thinks she’s got it.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Polly!  64.

dialogues.speaker: GAGA
dialogues.text: (frustrated) Paulie. Pauline. The little girls are really trying but they are unable to hear the distinction.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Polly.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Polline.

dialogues.speaker: GAGA
dialogues.text: What is the world coming to? Faith is fiercely concentrating. She says with extreme se consciousness in a faux British accent:

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: ‘Paul-ie.’

dialogues.speaker: GAGA
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. LATER
dialogues.text: The girls sit at a game table playing cards with Gaga. Ca enters, wearing his parka, carrying two large ancient coo sheets under his arm and a large roll of duct tape.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I’m going out to work on the car. As Gaga shuffles the cards:

dialogues.speaker: GAGA
dialogues.text: The girls tell me it has no floor.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: It had no floor. (holding up cookie sheets) I found these in your kitchen vault. Betty said I could have them.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Cookie sheets?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You won't be able to step on them, but it’1ll keep out the cold air and detritus.  65. Amelia sighs and shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: GAGA
dialogues.text: Cam, I’m very proud of you for taking care of these darling girls all by yourself. I mostly use the Lincoln these days. I'd like you to have the Bentley. The girls scream and leap to their feet like Lottery winn

dialogues.speaker: INT. BENTLEY. MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Amelia and Faith are scrambling all over it, touching everything. They push every button. They run their hands over the smooth wood. They rest their cheeks against the leather and inhale. Amelia sits in the driver’s seat and waves through the windshield at her father, who is outsid looking at the car with apprehension, smoking a cigarette

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Gaga looks extremely displeased, both hands on her cane. stands across from her, hands in his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: We live in a rent-controlled apartment.

dialogues.speaker: GAGA
dialogues.text: I know that. I pay your rent.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: And we’re very grateful --

dialogues.speaker: GAGA
dialogues.text: Piffle. It’s dirt-cheap.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: The point is... I can’t afford to take care of the Bentley. I can’t even afford to fill up its gas tank.

dialogues.speaker: GAGA
dialogues.text: If you’re asking me for gas money --

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I’m not asking for gas money, Gaga. Cam suddenly becomes nervous, uneasy. This is hard for hi  66.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: The girls are both phenomenal students... they’re not being challenged. If you really want to help, I think they would flourish in private school. Beat. She scowls at him.

dialogues.speaker: GAGA
dialogues.text: I don’t think that’s teaching the girls a very good lesson, do you? Cam looks confused, then resigned:

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I suppose not. Gaga takes his hand in an attempt to be supportive:

dialogues.speaker: GAGA
dialogues.text: We all believe in you, Cameron. We know it’s not too late for you to amount to something.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALIANT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: They drive home in silence. The girls pout in the back se

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Girls, look. I’m sorry we can’t take the Bentley. It just doesn’t make sense. I know it’s disappointing. They don’t respond. Then, in a coldly rational voice:

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: You should've taken it and then sold it and bought the crepe cart and then you could’ve made lots of money and we wouldn’t be so poor.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Sweetie, although crepes may be delicious, they’re not exactly the goldmine you think they are. Especially during a recession.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Well, then we could’ve sold the Bentley and just had some money.  67.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (sighing) Gaga would never let me sell that car.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: But she was giving it to you.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: That’s not how it works. It’s hard to explain. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: It was our one chance to have something that other people might want. Nobody wants what we have. They ride on in silence.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TRAIN STATION. DAY
dialogues.text: Maggie walks out of the station, with Cam and the girls. carries her suitcase. The girls brim over with excitement

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: We have a surprise for you. They can’t contain themselves. They run to the Valiant. Maggie slows as she approaches the car. Inside, a DOG is barking like mad and scrambling back and forth over the seats. Cam whistles and when the dog sees him, he starts whining and wagging his tail, scratching at the windows.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: That’s Jock! That’s our dog!

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Daddy got him for us!

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Amelia named him!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Why is he acting like that?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: He was abused by his last owner. So any time Daddy leaves him he gets really upset.  68.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Because he loves Daddy! Because Daddy saved him! As Cam puts the suitcase in the trunk:

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: We're working on it. Maggie looks unenthusiastic.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: And this is the new car?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: It was abused by its last owner. But Daddy saved it! Cam opens the passenger side door for her, with a flouris Jock streaks out and tears down the sidewalk, going after another dog who is on a leash. Cam and the girls race aft him.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Jock! No! Bad dog! Jock! It is chaos.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RAYMOND PARK. DAY
dialogues.text: Bundled up, the family kicks a soccer ball around. Jock r between them. Some distance away Kim and Ali watch from t swings. Cam sees them.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Don’t those little girls live in our building?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Yes. But they’re really mean.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (amused) Mean? They’re wearing identical pink parkas. How mean can they be? (calling) Hey! Hey! He waves at them to come over. Hesitant, they do.  69.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RAYMOND PARK. LATER
dialogues.text: Maggie sits on a bench with Faith in her lap. Cam plays a spirited soccer game with all the little kids in the park The ball comes toward Cam, who is smoking. He throws down his cigarette and dodges a kid, then passes the ball to K then picks up his cigarette again when the ball is gone.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT BUILDING HALLWAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The girls both hold onto Jock’s leash as they walk toward apartment. Cam and Maggie follow behind.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: They seem like nice kids. You should have them over sometime. Both girls scowl at him over their shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I'd rather die than have people over to our shithole. The girls take off running down the hall. Cam looks exhausted. Maggie looks at him; he shrugs, beleaguered.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: They crush my soul.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. APARTMENT BUILDING. DAY
dialogues.text: Spring. The early crocuses are coming up.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The apartment is a disaster. Art materials lie all over t table. Amelia bangs out a song on the piano and sings at top of her lungs while Faith does a dramatic dance. They both in their nightgowns.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: “Here we come, here we come, we're the pirates, and we're going to make you swab the decks..."  70.

dialogues.speaker: CAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (calling from the kitchen) Faithie-bear, could you clean your stuff off the dining room table?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (twirling) I’m busy. Cam emerges from the kitchen, a mixing bowl in his arms. is whisking something and wearing a utilitarian apron.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Dinner will be ready soon. It would be awfully nice to have a place to sit down and eat it.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Later! Cam watches, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Now. Now. She keeps dancing. Suddenly Cam explodes, HURLING THE BOW AT THE WALL.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Now! Both girls are startled out of their musical reverie. The Faith explodes:

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You are so MEAN! I am not your

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: No! I’m the goddamn servant! All I do is cook for you and drive you around and tend to your every need... He watches, furious, as she stomps by him.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: ...-you treat me like a goddamn maid! Cam turns off the stove. Grabs his overcoat and scarf.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I’ve got to get out of here.  71. Amelia jumps up from the piano and gets in his way.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: We don’t have a babysitter.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You don’t need a babysitter.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: But it’s night-time. We get scared. Faith gets scared. Cam looks for his keys, wallet.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You need to toughen up. What is there to be scared of? Wolves? Vampires?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Rapists. Cam shakes his head and puts on his coat.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: If a rapist knocks, don’t let him in.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: What if they force their way in? That's what rapists do!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Just kick him in the balls! Amelia runs to block the door. Jock starts barking and jumping around.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: (panicked) No, Daddy. Don’t go. Amelia drops to the ground and grabs Cam’s leg.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I don’t get it. You never want to be seen with me, you won’t have your friends over, you won’t let me talk to people -- I can’t take it anymore! I need to spend time with adults, not a bunch of bossy brats! Unhand my foot!  72. Cam leaves the apartment, slamming the door behind him. T dog barks constantly.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cam steams down the hall. Punches the elevator button. Waiting at the elevator, he pulls a pack of cigarettes fr his pocket. He looks up. At the end of the hall his daughters stand i their nightgowns and look at him silently, mournfully. Th elevator door opens. We can still hear the dog barking. He gives them the finger. Charges onto the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ELEVATOR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cam is agitated. He runs his hands through his hair. He punches the wall.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOBBY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Ruth-Ann waits for the elevator. The door opens to reveal Cam, sitting dejected on the floor. She hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH-ANN
dialogues.text: Going up?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (defeated) I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cam walks back down the hall to the apartment. He unlocks the door, but the chain is up. It stops him. He sighs wit frustration, then hurls his shoulder into the door, busti the chain and sending the door smashing open. The girls scream, alarmed, and jump to their feet. Amelia holds a baseball bat, Faith holds a cricket bat. Then the see it’s him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cam walks in. As he lights a cigarette:  73.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (worn-down ) You see, girls? That chain is worthless. The only thing it provides is a false sense of security, and that’s the last thing you girls need. He hugs them and they hug him back.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: We'll be braver, Daddy, I promise. Next time we'll be braver. He nods and heads back toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Cam cleans up the bowl and its contents that are spilled over the wall and floor.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Cam replaces the chain on the door with a deadbolt lock.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cam lies on the sofa, watching TV, drinking a beer, smoki He flips through the channels. He finishes the beer and crumples it. It joins four other crumpled cans. He reache for another. He looks depressed.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALIANT. DAY
dialogues.text: Cam, rumpled and low-energy, sits behind the wheel. The girls sit in the back seat. As Maggie gets in the car, sh sees that Cam has a huge bandage that covers his entire h and forearm. It looks like a giant q-tip.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Cam, what happened?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: What? Oh. Broke up a dog fight. Stupid. (beat) We had to give Jock away.  74.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. APARTMENT BUILDING. DAY
dialogues.text: The swimming pool is being filled. All the kids in the building stand outside the chain link fence watching with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALIANT. DAY
dialogues.text: Cam, still low-energy, waits in the car. Maggie opens the door. The bandages on his hand are gone.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: The girls didn’t want to come?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: It got old.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Maggie carries her suitcase over to the sofa in the livin room. She surveys the messy room, which now has a mini- trampoline in the middle of the rug. She stares at the mi trampoline, incredulous. Faith runs in.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Look what we found in the trash! Faith happily starts jumping up and down on it, doing spl in the air.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN. DAY
dialogues.text: Cam stands at the open fridge, staring into it, uninspire Amelia and Faith, wearing bathing suits, charge into the kitchen full of energy. Amelia grabs bread, peanut butter jam and milk. Faith hops up on the counter and pulls down two glasses, two plates. Amelia slaps together two sandwiches and Faith pours two glasses of milk. The girls leave the kitchen, each gingerly carrying a plate and a v full glass of milk. Cam still stares into the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TRAIN STATION. DAY
dialogues.text: Cam waits in the car double-parked. He is driving a red Toyota station wagon with one gray door. Maggie is confus as she gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What happened to the Valiant?  75.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Didn't I tell you? It caught on fire.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. APARTMENT BUILDING. DAY
dialogues.text: The swimming pool is being drained. Amelia, Faith, Kim, A and Thurgood stand outside the chain link fence with thei bicycles, watching sadly as a tarp is pulled over it. Aft a few moments, they hop on their bikes and pedal away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: September. Amelia and Faith walk to school in a large and lively group of children, all wearing big backpacks.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Cam sits in his red armchair, watching TV, smoking. He is unshaven and unkempt. He wears tube socks, a red smoking jacket and tight tennis shorts. Amelia marches in and tap a sign on the TV screen that reads “SMOKING SUCKS AND THE YOU DIE!” Faith tapes one underneath with a picture of a black lung that says: “DEAD SMOKER’S ACTUAL LUNG!” Cam stares blankly at the signs taped to the television. does not stop smoking. Then:

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I’m depressed. Amelia sits down on the floor and starts tying her sneake

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Of course you are. Your family gives you just barely enough money to live on, you can’t hold down a job, and you annoy people.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You left out my hemorrhoids.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (to Amelia) Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Out. I’m meeting Kim and Ali.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Can I come?  76.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: (half-hearted) I guess.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Can I come?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA/FAITH
dialogues.text: (outraged) No! God! We’re going to hang out with our friends!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: How come you never invite your friends over here?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: To this shithole?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Stop saying that.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Daddy, you can’t hang around with kids. It’s weird.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: We need to have our own lives. And you need your own life --

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: How am I supposed to have my own life when you won’t let me do anything -- They leave, slamming the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY. MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Amelia and Faith wait by the elevator. Cam opens the apartment door and stands at the end of the hall, looking them mournfully. They are both furious. They look away. They look back. He is still staring at them. They exchang a look. They are pained by his misery. Finally, they relent:

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Fine. We’re hanging out at the picnic tables. The elevator doors open. The girls get on.  77.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CONCRETE PARK. DAY
dialogues.text: Kim, Ali and Thurgood sit at the metal picnic tables. Fai and Amelia are across from them. Amelia has her Tarot car and she is doing a Tarot reading. She flips a card.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: The Death card.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Does that mean I’m going to die?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Not necessarily... Cam stands at the end of the table, digging stuff out of pockets, looking for matches.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Any of you kids got a light? Amelia and Faith shoot him a withering look. Amelia start gathering her Tarot cards.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: (to Kim) Can we finish this at your apartment?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Our parents don’t want us to have anyone over. We just got a new sectional. Amelia looks at Thurgood who shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: THURGOOD
dialogues.text: My older brother is studying for law school -- he freaks out if there’s kid noise.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You're all welcome to come over to our apartment... Faith and Amelia look at each other, furious. They both glare at him.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Cam, can we speak to you for a minute? Faith and Amelia pull him aside, away from the other kids Cam looks uneasy.  78.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: I am about to lose my shit. We said you could come hang out with us. We did not say you could invite people into the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: But I think it could be fun --

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: No. Not fun. Humiliating.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Do we need to spell it out for you?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: But I’1l make tea for everybody. And cinnamon toast. We’ve got lots of board games --

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: (hissing) We don’t want people to see how we live!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (exploding) Big deal how you live! It’s not your fault! Tell them your Dad’s manic-depressive or bi-polar or whatever they’re calling it these days! Don’t not have friends because of me! The girls are thrown by this outburst. Cam slumps.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Fuck it. Forget it. Never mind. He turns and walks back to the building, defeated. Faith Amelia look at each other, considering.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT BUILDING HALLWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: Amelia and Faith stand outside their apartment with Thurg Kim and Ali. Amelia takes her keys from around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: I’m warning you. You’ve never seen anything like this.

dialogues.speaker: THURGOOD
dialogues.text: I’ve been to messy houses before.  79. Faith raises her eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Not like this.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: (whispering) I’1l run and close Daddy’s door. Faith nods. Amelia opens the door and darts in. Faith blocks the doorway. INT. APARTMENT —- CAM’S BEDROOM. DAY Cam sits at his desk. A radio has been pulled apart and h is soldering a circuit board. His room looks like a bomb exploded. Amelia pokes her head in the door.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: We brought some friends over. Cam blinks, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Really? Amelia nods and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Amelia and Faith stand in the middle of the squalor with Thurgood, Kim and Ali, who seem stunned by the mess.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Why do you have so much stuff?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (with authority) Our Dad is totally Polar-Bear.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: (to Faith, correcting) Bi-polar. (to the rest, explaining) Manic-depressive.

dialogues.speaker: THURGOOD
dialogues.text: I have an uncle with that. He also lives like a pig.  80.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Hey! This is cool! Kim happily bounces on the mini-trampoline in the middle all the squalor.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The children fill the living room: Amelia, Faith and Ali play Roulette. Thurgood sits cross-legged on the mini-trampoline, bounci gently and staring at the album cover of “Guys and Dolls. Kim examines an old wooden cane. She pulls the handle and sword comes out. She is totally amazed. Cam emerges from the kitchen with a teapot and a plate of cinnamon toast points. He serves them all toast and refil their teacups. Cam has never seemed happier.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Would anyone like to learn how to make chocolate truffles from scratch?

dialogues.speaker: THURGOOD
dialogues.text: Me! He leaps to his feet and follows Cam into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HILLSIDE. DAY
dialogues.text: Cam comes into view, striding up the hill, whacking at th tall grasses with his machete. Behind him, the children begin to appear; they march behind him, fanning out on ei side, talking and laughing: Amelia, Faith, Kim, Ali, Thurgood, and three other kids from school.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODS. LATER
dialogues.text: The gang of children spreads out, searching the ground fo mushrooms and playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children sit on a fallen tree trunk, watching, as Cam demonstrates on Amelia how to twist someone’s arm behind their back. Amelia grabs his arm and does it to him.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Cam crams the kids into the Toyota. He lays the boys down the way back like cord wood. The engine turns over twice starts. The car is weighed down and drags in the back as drives slowly down the dirt road.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN. DAY
dialogues.text: Amelia watches as Maggie frosts a birthday cake. Maggie starts to pipe “Happy Birthday Faith” in white icing on t top.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: I don’t think I’m black.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Of course you’re black.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: But I look white.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Sweetie, you’re black.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Faith looks black. I look like Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You’re a mix of both of us.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Nobody thinks I’m black. When I tell them. Nobody thinks I look like you.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Amelia, I am black. Your mother is black. So you’re black. Maggie runs out of space on the cake, halfway through “Faith.”

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Damn it. She throws down the pastry bag. Amelia feels guilty.  82.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: You know, you and Daddy could go out to dinner some time. We don’t need a babysitter.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You don’t? Amelia shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: We used to get scared, but we’re not scared anymore. Maggie puts her hand on Amelia’s head and looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You’ve gotten so old.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: (smiling) If it makes you feel better, I’1l tell people I’m black. Even if they think I’m delusional.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cam and Maggie walk to a restaurant. They are both nicely dressed, wearing scarves and overcoats.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I think the last time we were at Legal Seafood, Faith pulled shrimp scampi all over my silk blouse.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You were so sad.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It was my best shirt.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: That was the same dinner where she trundled across the room and punched me right in the nuts.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (laughing) You were so sad. He nods, laughs.  83.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Amelia told me she doesn’t think she’s black.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: What? Her mother’s black. She’s just testing you, being feisty. She smiles at him with real gratitude. She links her arm through his.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: She also said they’re not scared anymore. The girls seem to be ina really good place.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: No kidding. Amelia beat up the class bully last week. Kicked him so hard in the knee she put him on crutches.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I felt quite proud.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You seem good too, Cam.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: So do you. Well whaddaya know.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'll be so happy when I get a job and I’m back here. Thanks for making it possible. Maggie smiles at Cam. He pulls her closer.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Stop sleeping on the sofa. Let’s sleep in a bed together. Maggie laughs but doesn’t pull away.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Cam, I can’t go in your room.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Why not?  84.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It’s beyond belief. You have three bicycles in there. Cam looks flabbergasted.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: That’s your reason?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes! There are cans of paint thinner -- and the last time I went in there I got motor oil on my skirt. I mean it’s... it’s ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Then I’1l clean it up. Maggie laughs, teasing him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That would be nice. It would make it more inviting.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You never said anything about this before.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m done nagging you to clean your room, you're a grown man and it’s your room.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: And my room is not inviting to you?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (amused) No! Not to me or anybody else. Probably not even to you. Cam laughs, good-naturedly.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Definitely not to me. I’m cleaning it up. It’1ll take me two days tops. You’ll see. It’ll bea thing of beauty. They walk on.  85.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FINANCIAL FIRM. DAY
dialogues.text: Maggie sits in a waiting room, professionally dressed, completely pulled together. Across from her sit three handsome 24-year-old white men. Suits, ties, polished sho They are talking, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN 1
dialogues.text: ...of course I know Jim Quincy! We were in the Delphic together at Harvard... I actually won this belt off him --

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Maggie Stuart? Maggie stands. The young men look at her like she’s a curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PLUSH OFFICE. DAY
dialogues.text: Maggie sits across from three fifty-year-old versions of young men in the waiting room.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: .-.I’m graduating at the top of my class and I’ve actually been offered a futures job at E.F. Hutton in New York, but Howard and Company is where I want to be.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN 1
dialogues.text: E.F. Hutton, that’s terrific. Why come back to Boston?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: My children are here -- Beat. Their eyes glaze over. Maggie instantly regrets mentioning her children.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN 1
dialogues.text: (politely) And how old are your children?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Twelve and ten. Very independent. Which allows me to come in early and work late --  86.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN 1
dialogues.text: (smiling) Thank you so much. We'll let you know. The men stand up, signalling the end of the meeting.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FINANCIAL FIRM. DAY
dialogues.text: As Maggie walks past three young men in their nice suits ties, she understands her prospects.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: Maggie waits on a corner in downtown Boston. She looks co and unhappy. She looks up the street and sees the red Toy wildly backing down the one-way street. Irate drivers hon at Cam. He stops in front of her. She gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: How'd the interview go? Maggie puts on an upbeat front.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Really well I think! I know a lot of people are vying for this position, but I think I’m very qualified. And I’ve got some more interviews.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Any one of these places would be lucky to have you. She smiles at him gratefully. INT. CAM’'S BEDROOM. DAY Cam stands in the middle of his messy bedroom, pulling ex books off the shelf and putting them in a box. He comes across The Collected Poems of Robert Frost. He opens the book. He sits down on the edge of the bed, reading. Amelia calls from the kitchen:  87.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Daddy, do I add more butter for each omelette? As Cam turns the page:

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (yelling) Half a tablespoon and make sure you let it get nut-brown. Faith steps into the doorway. She is festooned with gold pink ribbons wrapped around her arms and upper torso.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Did you start my costume?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: ...What costume?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You know. My Flamenco dancer costume for the talent show. You're making me a skirt. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (concerned) Daddy, it’s tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (lamely) Right. I know.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I knew it! You’re not making it.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I am making it. I said I would make it and I will.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Can you even sew?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Hey, I was in the army.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I want it to be all sparkly and ruffly.  88.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You got it, buggins. Faith claps her hands and excitedly breaks into her stomp Flamenco dance. The neighbor below bangs on the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cam opens a closet door and hauls Maggie’s sewing machine the top shelf.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Dining room table. Cam sits in front of the sewing machin a cigarette dangling from his lips. He studies Faith’s Flamenco doll.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I just have to make this skirt, two hundred times bigger.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: He draws a pattern on the pink satin fabric. He cuts out pattern, smoking all the while. A huge amount of ash drop on the fabric. He doesn’t notice.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: He pushes the fabric through the sewing machine. This way That way. The table is covered with dirty coffee cups. Hi ashtray overflows with cigarette butts. He screws up a se

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Goddamnit! I can’t do it! I can’t fucking do it! He yanks the fabric out of the sewing machine, throws it the floor, jumps on it, picks it up, throws it at the wal it flutters to the floor. This only fuels his rage. He spastically grabs it, crosses to the open window and hurl out the unfinished skirt. He pushes his hair back, looks around wild-eyed and crazy.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. APARTMENT BUILDING. NIGHT
dialogues.text: He wades through a bush to retrieve the skirt.  89.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cam has returned to working on the skirt. He sews a ruffl on. He turns to the flamenco doll.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Your skirt is a joke compared to what this skirt is going to look like. Cam downs the last of a cup of coffee, cracks open a beer takes a swig.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cam stands at the open window, drinking a beer. He picks the phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (sleepily) .--hello?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (into phone) Guess what I did?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: She turns on her bedside lamp and sits up, trying to orie herself.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Cam... it’s almost four in the morning. Cam examines the skirt with pride.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I just made your daughter an incredible skirt. Sparkles, ruffles... It’s probably my greatest achievement since I rebuilt the engine to my Dad’s Studebaker in college.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That’s terrific, Cam. You should probably get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I don’t want to sleep.  90.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: But you must be tired --

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: But I’m not tired. Maggie sits up.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Cam, you know how important sleep is to --

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Come on, Maggie! Name me one other father in America who is up right now sewing their daughter a flamenco skirt!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Cam... You are taking your lithium... aren’t you? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Actually, I haven’t taken my lithium since you left. Maggie hangs her head.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I find that if I take small, steady sips of beer throughout the day, it keeps me on an even keel... He takes a long, loud, defiant sip of his beer.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Abhh... Maggie looks stricken.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. MORNING
dialogues.text: Cam sits on the floor surrounded by bits of fabric. Faith manages to squeeze into the very beautiful and way tight skirt. It is so tight all the way down, she can bar move her legs. She finally gets it on and stares down at She wiggles to make the ruffle move. Then:

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I look like a flamenco mermaid!  91. She hops over to Cam, throws her arms around his neck and says dramatically:

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: It’s the most glorious skirt I’ve ever known!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STATION. SAME DAY
dialogues.text: Maggie walks out of the train station. Cam is double-park He wears his battered corduroy jacket and an Oxford shirt Maggie gets in the car, closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit in silence.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I’m not manic.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: But you could be.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I was excited. People are allowed to get excited when they can’t sew worth a damn and they manage to pull off a flamenco skirt that gets their daughter the second-most applause at the talent show.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RESTAURANT. DAY
dialogues.text: A tony Boston restaurant. The lunch crowd is well-dressed Cam and Maggie cross to sit down at the bar. Cam is angry

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You promised to take your lithium.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: And you promised to love me for better or for worse. The MAITRE D’ hurries over to them. MAITRE D’ Excuse me, sir. But our dress code requires you to wear a tie... Without missing a beat, Cam pulls an untied bowtie out of jacket pocket. As he ties it without looking:  92.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Let me say one thing about lithium - - no one even knows if it works. Same goes for haldol, valproic acid, and all their other so-called treatments. I’m just a guinea pig. And you never would’ve known I'd stopped taking it if I hadn’t told you. I’m an idiot. A fucking self- destructive fuckhead. His bowtie is perfectly tied. The Maitre D’ nods and quic retreats from this conversation.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Cam, you said you would take responsibility for your condition --

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: The way you’ve taken responsibility for your children?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That’s not fair. You know how hard this was for me.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I know, I know, it was hard to come every weekend...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No! It wasn’t hard to come, it wasn’t hard to come... Tears suddenly roll down Maggie’s face. Cam is startled.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: ...it was hard to leave. Every weekend. And have people think I was the worst mother in the world because I wanted my children to have a better life and I didn’t see any other way to get it. You’re from an old blue-blood family. When you live in squalor, it’s “eccentric.” When black people live in squalor, believe me, no one is charmed. Cam is quiet for a moment as that sinks in.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: If it’s any consolation, no one seems charmed by my squalor either. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAM (cont'd) (beat) I haven’t made any headway on my bedroom. Maggie looks at him and nods, resigned. Then:

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m going to take the E.F. Hutton job. In New York. It’s my only offer.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: New York? Maggie, I can’t keep doing this all by myself -- She puts her hand on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m not asking you to. You've done an amazing job. It’s time for me to take the girls. Cam reacts.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You're taking the girls to New York? But what about me and you? What about us? Maggie looks away. She is anguished. Cam seethes.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I knew it. I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: There’s so much I love about you, Cam. And I don’t want to give up on you. But I just... I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: So were you even trying to get a job here? Or was this your plan all along?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No! My plan was to come home and maybe I’d be with you and maybe I wouldn’t, but we’d still be a family. But none of that matters. These Boston firms don’t want me.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Why don’t they want you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Because, Cam, this is Boston. They want people like you. This hits Cam like a ton of bricks. His face hardens.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You want a job in Boston? I’1l get you a job in Boston! Cam stands and storms out of the restaurant. INT. DICK’S OFFICE. DAY DICK, 40, sits behind a large oak desk with a view onto t financial district. He wears a suit and tie. He is tall, handsome and athletic. The walls are hung with pictures o sailboats. Cam sits across from him. Cam is agitated.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: You look well, Cam. Everything good down your way?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Not really, Dickie. No.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Sorry to hear that --

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: As you know, Maggie’s just gotten her MBA.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I heard. Good for her.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I was wondering why there isn’t a place for her here. It is a family firm, after all. Dick sighs and looks sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Well, Cam, I wish there were. But we just don’t have the position at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: So you're telling me that when Dickie Jr and...the other one... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAM (cont'd) graduate from college, they won't land here?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Sumner. That’s my other son --

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: God damn it, Dickie! I know how it works! You create the position!

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I have to say, Cam, this is why we never invite you to the Christmas party.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I don’t give a shit about your Christmas party. I want you to hire my wife. She works fifty thousand times harder than any of you! Dick gets up from the desk.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I have to ask you to leave.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea how hard it is? Do you have any idea what sacrifices she’s made? She needs a job here! In Boston! Cam picks up a model sailboat and hurls it at the wall.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Cam! Stop it! Snap out of it! Cam picks up a chair and throws it at the bookcase, which comes down. Dick tackles him to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Two SECURITY OFFICERS escort Cam out. Dick puts his hand Cam’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Just so you know, I won’t tell Gaga about this. Cam looks at him, resigned.  96.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Maggie sits on the sofa, folding laundry. The front door opens. She hears Cam walk down the hall to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Cam? Cam?

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT BATHROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cam stands at the sink, filling a glass of water. He is soaking wet from head to toe. Maggie comes to the doorway the bathroom. She is startled by his appearance.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Why are you wet? Cam doesn’t look at her. He takes out his bottle of lithi

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Girls asleep? She nods. He empties three large pills into his hand.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Faith show you her skirt?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes. It’s beautiful. Cam swallows the pills with the full glass of water. He closes the medicine cabinet and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I couldn't get you a job in Boston. As he walks past her into his bedroom:

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I jumped in the Charles River. INT. APARTMENT CAM’S BEDROOM. CONTINUOUS His bedroom is a pit. Cam sits down on his bed, among the piles of clothes.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I’m just going to miss them is all. Maggie nods, with great sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. 97. She exits, gently closing the door. Cam looks around at h room, the manifestation of failure.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ICE CREAM PARLOR. DAY
dialogues.text: Amelia and Faith sit at a round table, ice cream sundaes front of them. Maggie and Cam sit across.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Isn't New York really expensive? Where are we going to live?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'll find an apartment in a very safe neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Where will we go to school?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I‘1ll figure that out.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: We can’t ride bikes in New York.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You can ride your bikes when you come here.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: What about Daddy? Who’s going to take care of him?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Daddy will take care of himself.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I'll go to dinner parties, movies, I’ll have escapades. Faith and Amelia look disapproving.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: I think escapades are a bad idea. He could end up in jail.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: If we’re not here, he’1l drink too much and stop taking care of himself.  98.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: That’s not true.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: He’1ll be lonely without us.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Well, that’s true.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Taking care of you alone has been a lot of pressure for your father.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: How? We get to school...

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: .--he drives us anywhere we want to go...

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: ...we’ve seen more r-rated movies than any of our friends...

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: ...plus he makes us french toast for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He needs a break.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: When I had the flu, he cut up strawberries and kiwis for me. And he arranged them on the plate like little flowers. Maggie looks at Cam. He shrugs modestly.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I did do that. I did that.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Daddy will visit and you’1l visit him. New York is an incredible city. You'll like it. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) What a crock. Maggie is speechless. Cam nods at her.  99.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Get used to it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CONCRETE PARK. DAY
dialogues.text: A hibachi engulfed in flame. PULL BACK TO REVEAL: Cam grills shishkebabs by the metal picnic tables. Though is a chilly day, he wears denim overalls, a striped denim workshirt and a denim cap. The girls play Chinese jumprop with Kim and Ali at the other end of the park. Maggie sit at the picnic table, near Cam, watching her daughters pla with their friends. Thurgood runs into the park area and stops in front of Ca

dialogues.speaker: THURGOOD
dialogues.text: You've been working on the railroad.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: All the live-long day. Thurgood laughs and runs off to join the other kids. Magg smiles. Cam stares into the fire.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I can’t visit you in New York. Too much speed and noise and all the people out on the streets all night. Winds me up. Knocks me off track.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (nods ) I was just thinking about that.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I do understand why you don’t want to live with me. I’m a much better father than I was a husband.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You know what Faith said to me last night? She said: “You don’t lose your temper like Daddy and you keep the apartment nice, but the thing about Daddy is he’s always around. He’s always there.”

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I thought that irritated them.  100. He reaches through the flames and turns the shishkebabs w long metal tongs. Maggie stares off. Then she takes a dee breath.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I have a plan. I take this job and earn some money. The girls stay here with you. They keep riding their bikes. They stay with their friends. But we get them into a good private school where they can be challenged. I insist on that.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Maggie. Are you sure? Maggie stands and walks over to Cam.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: If they come to New York they’1l be shut up like house pets in some dark apartment and I'1l be working till eight o’clock at night, every night. I don’t want that for them. Maggie looks over at the girls. Her heart breaks.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: They're my babies. Maggie buries her face in her hands. Cam holds out his ar

dialogues.speaker: THE CHINESE JUMPROPE
dialogues.text: Amelia is jumping. Kim looks over Amelia’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: I thought your parents were divorced.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (sighing) No, they're married.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: But your Mom doesn’t live with you?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: No. Except on the weekends.

dialogues.speaker: THURGOOD
dialogues.text: So are they married on the weekends?  101.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Sort of, not really... Amelia turns to look at her parents at the other end of t park. Maggie has collapsed into Cam’s arms and she is sobbing. Cam is sobbing too. He still holds the metal tongs. Amelia watches them for a long time. Then:

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: It’s hard to explain.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TOYOTA STATION WAGON. DAY
dialogues.text: Cam drives the car on the highway, smoking. A CAT is drap over Cam’s shoulders while he drives. The girls are sleep in the backseat under a blanket. Amelia yawns and stirs.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Daddy? How much longer?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (pleasantly surprised) You’re awake. I thought you were going to sleep the whole way home. He quickly stabs out his cigarette. Faith squirms awake.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: We just crossed into Massachusetts. We're making great time. Faith climbs into the front passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You both conked out so quickly. Must’ve been a fun weekend.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: It was. Mommy let me do her hair. Cam drives. It’s quiet for a moment. Amelia sits up and stares out the window, then:

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Do you know that Mommy has a boyfriend in New York?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Of course I know.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: He’s nice. But I don’t like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Oh boy. Poor Mommy.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Why poor Mommy?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Because it’s hard to conduct a romance when your children are gunning for your lover.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA/FAITH
dialogues.text: Ew! Lover!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Lover, swain, beau, whatever.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: How come you always feel so sorry for Mommy? Cam sighs and looks sad.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Because Mommy tries hard. She wanted things to go differently.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Me too. Cam smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Me three. The girls laugh. Then Faith looks back at her sister and rolls her eyes with irritation.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Daddy, Amelia’s about to cry. Cam looks in the rearview at Amelia who is crying.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Big Little... what is it?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: I just... I worry about you.  103.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Please, darling. Don’t worry about me. I’11 be fine. They drive in silence. Then, starting in an absurdly deep voice, Cam breaks into “Annie Laurie.” He sings in a full Scottish brogue, his voice getting very high and squeaky forlorn on the chorus.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Maxwellton Braes are bonnie Where early lies the dew Twas there that Annie Laurie Gave me her Promise True Gave me her promise true... And ne'er forgot shall be... For Bonnie Annie Laurie, I'd lay me doon and dee... The girls join in. As they sing, a series of cuts: -- Cam takes Amelia and Faith on a walk through Mt. Aubur Cemetery. -- Amelia runs between the shelves of books in an overstu bookstore. She rounds the corner and nestles in next to C who sits on the floor, with Faith on his lap. -- Cam proudly leads Amelia, Faith, Thurgood, Kim and Ali a tour through the grand old mansion on Beacon Hill. The children are blown away by the splendor. As they file pas Mr. Fabrini on their way out, thanking him, he nods curtl and gives them all a very tight smile. He is clearly extremely annoyed by Cam and can’t wait to get rid of him Cam grins back at him, victorious.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. TOYOTA STATION WAGON. DAY
dialogues.text: They sing together.

dialogues.speaker: ALL THREE
dialogues.text: Like dew on the gowan lying Is the tread of her fairy feet And like winds in summer sighing Her voice is low and sweet Her voice is low and sweet... (high and squeaky) She's all the world to me... And for bonnie Annie Laurie, I'd lay me doon and dee...  104. They speed down the highway.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SHADY HILL SCHOOL ATHLETIC FIELDS. DAY
dialogues.text: AMELIA, wearing the school athletic uniform, her hair pul back in a tidy french braid, stands with eight other girl lacrosse practice. They are lined up, taking turns shooti on goal. A TITLE CARD READS: One year later. Amelia runs forward and fires a ball into the net.

dialogues.speaker: CAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nice shot, Amelia! Amelia waves at Cam, who is cheering from the sidelines. Another girl runs and shoots into the net.

dialogues.speaker: CAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nice shot, Amelia’s friend! Amelia jogs back to the line of girls.

dialogues.speaker: SHS TEAM MATE
dialogues.text: How come your dad always comes to practice?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: (matter-of-fact) He’s got nothing else to do.

dialogues.speaker: ON CAM
dialogues.text: He gives Amelia a thumbs up. He drops to his knee and tak some pictures.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Practice is over. Amelia is laughing with her friends as they put the lacrosse balls in a bag and pick up the cone Faith runs up to Amelia. Faith is wearing an SHS sweatshi and eyeglasses. Together the girls run over to Cam as he puts a new roll of film in his camera. The rest of the te heads back to the gym.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Daddy, Annie invited me for a sleepover, can I go? Please?  105.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: And Fifi asked if I wanted to go with her family to the movies.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: But I finally convinced Eliot Perkins to let me borrow his boat. I thought we could have a picnic on the river.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: It’s too late to go out on a boat.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: It’s four o’clock.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: I really want to go to Annie’s.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Maybe Annie wants to take a ride down the Charles River.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Daddy...

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I’m serious. She lives in Boston. How many times has she gotten a ride home on a boat? Now they are the only ones left on the field.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: She takes the T.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: (to Faith) What about Fifi, do you think she’d like to have a picnic on the water?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Her mom’s picking her up in twenty minutes. Please can I go?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You will never find a more beautiful boat or a more perfect day to go out on the river. They are unmoved. Cam shakes his head, giving up.  106.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Okay, well, I guess I'll tell the Charles River to go fuck itself. Both girls laugh at his ridiculous reaction.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Well, I have heard that the Charles River is a real asshole. Cam chuckles at that.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Thanks, Daddy. He nods. They both hug him. He hugs them back.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Bye, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Oh, darlings, I’m so proud of you. So's Mommy.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: We just are. They back away from him, waving, then turn and head acros the field. He stands, watching them go. They glance back over their shoulders, smile and wave again quickly. He wa mournfully. They quicken their pace. Then he calls out:

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I love you! They stop dead. They whirl around and steam toward him. They are completely enraged.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Don’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Watch us walk away.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I’m just watching you walk.  107.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Please don’t.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You make us feel bad.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to feel bad.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (stamping her foot) Yes, you do! That’s why you stand there looking all pathetic!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I’m just watching you walk across the field, for chrissake! I think I’m allowed! The girls sigh, frustrated. Amelia steps toward him, look him dead in the eye. She is stern, deliberate.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Daddy. We are walking away now. And we are not turning around. We are not looking back.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I’m not asking you too! They shake their heads.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (angry) We love you, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: (furious) We love you. Goodbye. The girls turn and link arms. They huddle close together walk away from him as quickly as they can. As they go, Fa glances at her sister with concern. She puts her hand ove Amelia's and squeezes it.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Don’t cry. Don’t cry. Tears stream down Amelia’s face.  108.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) Can’t help it.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Hands in his pockets, he watches them walk away. Pressed together, in lock-step, they cross the playing fields. Autumn leaves skitter around their feet. They keep walking. They do not turn around. They do not look back. Then, just before they recede from view, they stop and tu They face him from this great distance. He brightens and holds up his hand. They each hold up a hand. He makes a fist in the air as if to say courage, onward. The girls d the same. The three of them stand like that for a moment. Then Amelia and Faith turn and run in the opposite direct disappearing into the gymnasium. Cam looks up at the sky. He smiles to himself. He pulls a tam o’shanter with a red pompom from his pocket and puts on his head. He lights a cigarette and walks toward the river. FADE OUT.
